Turns out for the OSX peeps, MacFUSE isn't good enough to support git's file-access requirements.
So one of our OSX devs tried flipping it, and mounting the project files off his local disk from the VM, using a VirtualBox "virtual drive" or whatever it's called.
And the performance he reported was ridiculously terrible.
Ok, so vagrant evangelists: I've tried exactly one project with a distributed team using a VM for dev, and it was a nightmare.
and @bitprophet
@carljm I've not used the local files mount myself, nor have I run any Django projects with it yet, so unfortunately I can't answer those specific concerns.
Shared drive or something...
For one thing we didn't have vagrant; that would have made setup/provisioning easier.
You have to have the files available in your local system, so you can use your own VCS config, editor, etc.
Quite likely we were doing some things wrong, but I'm trying to nail down exactly what.
But even with that aside; we had major problems with devs just being able to have a sane development flow.
We tried that two ways: one was using FUSE and sshfs to access files on the VM over ssh.
Like, minutes just to start runserver in the VM.
On a relatively large Django project.
So - I'd be very curious to know what's the silver bullet we were missing. And then I'll go try out vagrant...
